Chief Complaint: GI bleed
   24 Hour Events:
   -EGD showed friability at site of anastamosis which was injected and
   blood in stomach.  Varices were noted in the lower third of the
   esophagus.
   - GI recommending repeat EGD with EUS when bleeding stops to evaluate
   for ulcers
   - could not get PICC due to long line for PICC
   - octreotide drip stopped because there was no evidence of bleeding
   varices
   - GI recommended checking a gastrin level
   - Hct 31.1 --> 28.8 --> 1 unit PRBCs --> 30.5 --> 29.0 --> 1 unit PRBCs
   - Hypernatremia improved with D5W 151 --> 147
   - Echo performed: Normal global biventricular systolic function.
   Limited study
   - iron studies show iron deficiency anemia so started on iron
   supplements
   *will need PICC placement or Left IJ today *
   Allergies:
   Aspirin
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Pantoprazole (Protonix) - 8 mg/hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Fentanyl - [**2172-10-22**] 09:30 AM
   Midazolam (Versed) - [**2172-10-22**] 10:00 AM
   Morphine Sulfate - [**2172-10-23**] 04:37 AM
   Other medications:
   Ferrous Sulfate 325 daily
   MVI
   Morphine [**1-13**] IV q 4 prn
   Digoxin 0.125  daily
   Methadone 5 mg TID

   Troponin-T:88/4/0.02, ALT / AST:40/32, Alk Phos / T Bili:39/0.8,
   Amylase / Lipase:/27, Differential-Neuts:79.5 %, Lymph:11.0 %, Mono:7.8
   %, Eos:1.4 %, Lactic Acid:1.0 mmol/L, Albumin:2.7 g/dL, LDH:273 IU/L,
   Ca++:8.6 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7 mg/dL, PO4:2.9 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   64 M with EtOH cirrhosis, PUD and multiple abdominal surgeries, and
   Afib, admit with upper GI bleed from anastamosis site now with
   significant abdominal pain concerning for SBO.
   UGIB.  Patient with ongoing slow bleed, requiring daily transusions.
   Unable to place peripheral IVs.  Has RIJ placed at OSH which will need
   to be pulled and replaced with IR guided PICC.  With melena and BRBPR
   in a cirrhotic patient.  Also with extensive history of PUD and
   multiple abdominal surgeries.  Initial EGD reportedly without varices
   or clear causes of bleeding.  Also awaiting CT abdomen and bleeding
   scan report (being faxed from [**Hospital1 632**]; CD/images not sent with him.
   - Liver consult and likely EGD (overnight if unstable, otherwise in
   AM).
   - If no source from EGD, will need further bleeding workup (repeat
   tagged RBC scan, colonoscopy, surgery consult).
   - Consider NGT and NGL (patient currently quite resistant to NGT
   placement while awake).
   - PPI gtt.
   - Octreotide gtt until varices ruled out.
   - No ascites per exam and CT findings, no SBP prophylaxis needed.
   - Type and screen, crossmatch 4 units.  Will transfuse for hematocrit <
   30.
   - Q4H hct and platelets.
   - Goal platelets > 50K, INR < 1.5.
   - Bolus IVFs/blood for hypotension/tachycardia; hold antihypertensives.
   .
   # Abdominal pain.  Patient also with GIB as above, though pain has been
   unchanged from baseline chronic abdominal pain thought related to
   chronic pancreatitis.  Extensive abdominal surgeries in history.
   Patient reports being told that surgeries would not be recommended
   given his history, but if there was a problem that could only be
   managed surgically, he would pursue this is he were a candidate.  CT
   abdomen at OSH on [**10-18**] with some concern for air within stomach
   wall/contained perforation vs. trapped within folds.  Had subsequent
   EGD that was unremarkable.  Abdomen currently tender but soft, no
   rigidity or rebound, per patient at baseline chronic pain.
   - obtain CT images vs. repeat here; holding off currently in
   anticipation of EGD here early AM.
   - may need eventual surgical consult.  Not currently with surgical
   abdomen.
   .
   # Afib.  Currently rate controlled.
   - Check echocardiogram.
   - Can continue digoxin; hold other nodal agents for time being.  Check
   digoxin level.
   - Would prefer to bolus IVFs or given blood initially to manage
   tachycardia, as will ongoing bleeding and likely intravascularly dry.
   .
   # Cirrhosis.  Presumed EtOH related.  Unclear prior workup.
   - Liver consult.
   - Collateral information.
   .
   # EtOH abuse. Sober x 10 years plus.
   - Multivitamin.
   .
   # Anemia.  Predominantly acute blood loss anemia.
   - Check B12, folate, Fe studies, TSH.
   # Thrombocytopenia.  Currently 125.  200 at OSH admission, down to 60
   with requirement of platelet transfusions.  Consumption with active
   bleed vs. iver disease vs. hypersplenism (but CT report notes
history
   of splenectomy
 in clinical history), also consider bone marrow
   suppression, med related.  No heparin exposures.  On PPI, no H2
   blockers.
   - Continue to trend.
   - Transfuse platelets <50, higher threshold if briskly bleeding.
   .
   # Renal insufficiency.  Creatinine now improved, was up to ~1.9 at
   OSH.  Contrast on [**10-18**].  Per past labs, 0.9 appears to be at baseline.
   - Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Hypernatremia.  Na up to 157 at OSH today, improved to 151 here after
   getting some D5W at 70/h.
   - Continue D5W for ~2 L further (free water deficit likely greater than
   this).
   .
   # Leukocytosis.  No evidence of infection.  [**Month (only) 11**] be stress response.
   - Blood and urine cultures.
   - CXR without infiltrate.
   - Elect to hold further antibiotic therapy (received ~5 days of Zosyn
   at OSH).
   .
   # Chronic pain.  continue home regimen of methadone; morphine prn.
   .
   # Weight loss.  Patient cachectic; reports weight loss of 10 pounds in
   last week, though nothing before that; unclear baseline weight.
   - checking thyroid.
   - consent for HIV.
   - EGD with biopsy, other malignancy workup likely following acute
   bleed.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO, D5W for hydration
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2172-10-22**] 06:38 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper GI bleed from anastomosis site. The patient has ongoing slow bleed, requiring daily transfusions, and has a risk of SBO. 

The patient has the following medical complications:

1. GI bleed: The patient has ongoing slow bleed from the anastomosis site, requiring daily transfusions.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is currently 125, which is down from 200 at admission, and is likely due to consumption with active bleed or underlying disease.
3. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level was previously elevated, but has improved to 0.9, which is at baseline.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level was previously elevated, but has improved to 147 with D5W therapy.
5. Anemia: The patient has predominantly acute blood loss anemia, and iron studies show iron deficiency anemia.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient has a white blood cell count of 11.9, which is likely due to a stress response.
7. Chronic pain: The patient has chronic abdominal pain, which is likely related to chronic pancreatitis and extensive abdominal surgeries.
8. Cirrhosis: The patient has presumed EtOH-related cirrhosis, which is being managed with a liver consult.
9. EtOH abuse: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse, but is currently sober.

The patient is at risk for the following potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a risk of sepsis due to the GI bleed and potential bacterial translocation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has a risk of respiratory failure due to the GI bleed and potential respiratory complications.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with digoxin, and is at risk for cardiac complications.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has cirrhosis, which increases the risk of hepatic encephalopathy.
5. GI bleeding complications: The patient is at risk for further GI bleeding complications, including perforation and hemorrhage.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Repeat EGD with EUS to evaluate for ulcers.
2. Continue octreotide drip until varices are ruled out.
3. Consider NGT and NGL for further management of GI bleed.
4. Continue PPI therapy.
5. Monitor for signs of sepsis and respiratory failure.
6. Continue to manage atrial fibrillation with digoxin.
7. Monitor for signs of hepatic encephalopathy.
8. Consider surgical consult if GI bleed is not controlled with medical management.
9. Monitor for signs of further GI bleeding complications.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted to the ICU with upper GI bleed from anastamosis site. The patient has ongoing slow bleeding, requiring daily transfusions.

The patient's laboratory results show iron deficiency anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal insufficiency. The patient's electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation, which is rate-controlled.

The patient's physical examination shows a thin general appearance, normal cardiovascular and respiratory exams, and soft abdomen with bowel sounds present and left-sided tenderness.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 114/65 mmHg.

The patient's medical history includes cirrhosis, pancreatitis, and multiple bowel surgeries, which may increase the risk of small bowel obstruction (SBO). The patient's abdominal pain is concerning for SBO, and a CT abdomen is planned to evaluate for air within the stomach wall or contained perforation.

The patient's medication list includes pantoprazole, fentanyl, midazolam, morphine, digoxin, and methadone.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's ongoing slow bleeding may require further transfusions, and the source of bleeding needs to be identified and treated.
2. Small bowel obstruction (SBO): The patient's history of multiple bowel surgeries and abdominal pain suggest an increased risk of SBO, which can lead to severe complications if not treated promptly.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to cirrhosis and chronic pancreatitis may increase the risk of infection, particularly in the setting of a GI bleed.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's history of renal insufficiency may worsen if the bleeding is not controlled, and the patient's creatinine level is already elevated.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if the bleeding is not controlled, and platelet transfusions may be necessary.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may require further treatment, and the patient's sodium level needs to be closely monitored.
7. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if the bleeding is not controlled, and the patient's heart rate and rhythm need to be closely monitored.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue pantoprazole drip to control bleeding.
2. Consider surgical consultation if the patient's bleeding does not respond to medical treatment.
3. Perform a tagged RBC scan or IR-guided PICC line placement to identify the source of bleeding.
4. Monitor the patient's platelet count and transfuse platelets if necessary.
5. Evaluate the patient for SBO and consider CT abdomen to rule out air within the stomach wall or contained perforation.
6. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely, and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Consider a liver consult to evaluate the patient's cirrhosis and potential liver disease.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary.
9. Consider a nutrition consult to evaluate the patient's nutritional needs and provide appropriate supplementation.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient has a history of anastomosis site friability, varices in the lower third of the esophagus, and iron deficiency anemia. The patient has received various medications, including pantoprazole, fentanyl, midazolam, and morphine, as well as iron supplements. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure of 114/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, hypernatremia, and liver enzymes elevated.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's anastomosis site friability and varices in the lower third of the esophagus pose a risk of continued bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and multi-organ failure.
2. Infection: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and use of invasive devices increase the risk of infection, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
3. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is critical, and excessive fluid administration could lead to fluid overload, pulmonary edema, and cardiac failure.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glycemic control is critical, and hypoglycemia could occur if the patient's glucose levels are not adequately monitored and managed.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypernatremia and other electrolyte abnormalities require close monitoring to prevent further imbalance and potential cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Liver failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and iron deficiency anemia pose a risk of liver failure, which could lead to multi-organ failure and poor prognosis.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypernatremia increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiac failure.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and anastomosis site friability pose a risk of further gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation, obstruction, or bleeding.
10. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and lack of oral intake increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies, particularly protein-energy malnutrition.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 M with EtOH cirrhosis, PUD and multiple abdominal surgeries, and
   Afib, admit with upper GI bleed.
   # UGIB.  With melena and BRBPR in a cirrhotic patient.  Also with
   extensive history of PUD and multiple abdominal surgeries.  Initial EGD
   reportedly without varices or clear causes of bleeding.  Also awaiting
   CT abdomen and bleeding scan report (being faxed from [**Hospital1 632**]; CD/images
   not sent with him.
   - Liver consult and likely EGD (overnight if unstable, otherwise in
   AM).
   - If no source from EGD, will need further bleeding workup (repeat
   tagged RBC scan, colonoscopy, surgery consult).
   - Consider NGT and NGL (patient currently quite resistant to NGT
   placement while awake).
   - PPI gtt.
   - Octreotide gtt until varices ruled out.
   - No ascites per exam and CT findings, no SBP prophylaxis needed.
   - Type and screen, crossmatch 4 units.  Will transfuse for hematocrit <
   30.
   - Q4H hct and platelets.
   - Goal platelets > 50K, INR < 1.5.
   - Bolus IVFs/blood for hypotension/tachycardia; hold antihypertensives.
   .
   # Abdominal pain.  Patient also with GIB as above, though pain has been
   unchanged from baseline chronic abdominal pain thought related to
   chronic pancreatitis.  Extensive abdominal surgeries in history.
   Patient reports being told that surgeries would not be recommended
   given his history, but if there was a problem that could only be
   managed surgically, he would pursue this is he were a candidate.  CT
   abdomen at OSH on [**10-18**] with some concern for air within stomach
   wall/contained perforation vs. trapped within folds.  Had subsequent
   EGD that was unremarkable.  Abdomen currently tender but soft, no
   rigidity or rebound, per patient at baseline chronic pain.
   - obtain CT images vs. repeat here; holding off currently in
   anticipation of EGD here early AM.
   - may need eventual surgical consult.  Not currently with surgical
   abdomen.
   .
   # Afib.  Currently rate controlled.
   - Check echocardiogram.
   - Can continue digoxin; hold other nodal agents for time being.  Check
   digoxin level.
   - Would prefer to bolus IVFs or given blood initially to manage
   tachycardia, as will ongoing bleeding and likely intravascularly dry.
   .
   # Cirrhosis.  Presumed EtOH related.  Unclear prior workup.
   - Liver consult.
   - Collateral information.
   .
   # EtOH abuse. Sober x 10 years plus.
   - Multivitamin.
   .
   # Anemia.  Predominantly acute blood loss anemia.
   - Check B12, folate, Fe studies, TSH.
   # Thrombocytopenia.  Currently 125.  200 at OSH admission, down to 60
   with requirement of platelet transfusions.  Consumption with active
   bleed vs. iver disease vs. hypersplenism (but CT report notes
history
   of splenectomy
 in clinical history), also consider bone marrow
   suppression, med related.  No heparin exposures.  On PPI, no H2
   blockers.
   - Continue to trend.
   - Transfuse platelets <50, higher threshold if briskly bleeding.
   .
   # Renal insufficiency.  Creatinine now improved, was up to ~1.9 at
   OSH.  Contrast on [**10-18**].  Per past labs, 0.9 appears to be at baseline.
   - Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Hypernatremia.  Na up to 157 at OSH today, improved to 151 here after
   getting some D5W at 70/h.
   - Continue D5W for ~2 L further (free water deficit likely greater than
   this).
   .
   # Leukocytosis.  No evidence of infection.  [**Month (only) 11**] be stress response.
   - Blood and urine cultures.
   - CXR without infiltrate.
   - Elect to hold further antibiotic therapy (received ~5 days of Zosyn
   at OSH).
   .
   # Chronic pain.  continue home regimen of methadone; morphine prn.
   .
   # Weight loss.  Patient cachectic; reports weight loss of 10 pounds in
   last week, though nothing before that; unclear baseline weight.
   - checking thyroid.
   - consent for HIV.
   - EGD with biopsy, other malignancy workup likely following acute
   bleed.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO, D5W for hydration
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2172-10-22**] 06:38 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper GI bleed. He has been diagnosed with varices in the lower third of the esophagus and friability at the site of anastomosis. He has been treated with octreotide drip, which was stopped due to lack of evidence of bleeding. He has been experiencing abdominal pain, which is chronic and thought to be related to chronic pancreatitis. He also has atrial fibrillation, cirrhosis, anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal insufficiency, hypernatremia, and leukocytosis.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Bleeding**: The patient's GI bleed is ongoing, and there is a risk of further bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
2. **Variceal bleeding**: The patient has varices in the lower third of the esophagus, which can rupture and lead to bleeding.
3. **Infection**: The patient has leukocytosis, which may indicate an underlying infection. Blood and urine cultures should be obtained to rule out infection.
4. **Renal failure**: The patient has renal insufficiency, which can worsen with further bleeding, infection, or hypovolemia.
5. **Hypovolemic shock**: The patient's bleeding can lead to hypovolemic shock, which can cause organ failure and death.
6. **Coagulopathy**: The patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia can increase the risk of bleeding and coagulopathy.
7. **Sepsis**: The patient's leukocytosis and infection risk can lead to sepsis, which can cause organ failure and death.
8. **Gastrointestinal perforation**: The patient's history of abdominal surgery and chronic pancreatitis can increase the risk of gastrointestinal perforation.
9. **Liver failure**: The patient's cirrhosis can worsen with further bleeding, infection, or hypovolemia, leading to liver failure.
10. **Cardiac complications**: The patient's atrial fibrillation can worsen with further bleeding, infection, or hypovolemia, leading to cardiac complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding and vital signs closely.
2. Obtain blood and urine cultures to rule out infection.
3. Continue to treat the patient's varices with octreotide drip.
4. Consider repeat EGD with EUS to evaluate for ulcers.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluids and medications accordingly.
6. Continue to transfuse blood products as needed to maintain hemoglobin levels above 30.
7. Monitor the patient's platelet count and transfuse platelets if necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluids and medications accordingly.
9. Consider surgical consultation if the patient's bleeding is not controlled with medical management.
10. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust medications accordingly.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper GI bleed from the anastomosis site. The patient has ongoing slow bleeding, requiring daily transfusions.

The patient has the following potential medical complications:

1. SBO (Small Bowel Obstruction): The patient has significant abdominal pain, which is concerning for SBO.
2. Variceal bleed: The patient has grade 1 esophageal varices, which can lead to further bleeding.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which can increase the risk of bleeding.
4. Anemia: The patient has acute blood loss anemia, which can lead to fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
5. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level was previously elevated, and there is a risk of further kidney damage.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level was previously elevated, and there is a risk of further electrolyte imbalance.
7. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which can be a sign of infection or inflammation.
8. Chronic pain: The patient has chronic abdominal pain, which can be managed with medication, but there is a risk of further complications.
9. Weight loss: The patient has lost 10 pounds in the last week, which can be a sign of malnutrition and increased risk of complications.
10. Liver disease: The patient has cirrhosis, which can lead to further liver damage and complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continuing PPI drip to manage bleeding.
2. Considering surgical consult if the patient continues to bleed.
3. TID Hcts to monitor for anemia.
4. PICC line placement today.
5. Liver consultation.
6. Multivitamin supplementation.
7. Monitoring of platelet count and transfusion if necessary.
8. Continuing D5W for hydration and electrolyte balance.
9. Blood and urine cultures to rule out infection.
10. Holding antibiotic therapy unless infection is confirmed.
11. Continuing home regimen of methadone and morphine for chronic pain.
12. Checking thyroid function and considering HIV testing.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the disposition is ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) with PUD and varices as potential etiologies. The patient has been bleeding slowly with a drop in hemoglobin (Hct) level. He has also developed tenderness in the left upper quadrant (LUQ) and mid epigastric region, which may indicate ileus, small bowel obstruction (SBO), or evolving pancreatitis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 125
* White blood cell count: 11.9-12.7 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.01-0.07 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 273 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.6 mg/dL
* Mg++: 1.7 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.9 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): Normal global biventricular systolic function, with mild thickening of the aortic valve leaflets and trivial mitral regurgitation.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* EtOH cirrhosis
* PUD
* Varices
* Afib
* Chronic pain
* Renal insufficiency
* Hypernatremia
* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's plan includes:

* Further evaluation of abdominal pain
* Hct and platelet count monitoring
* Bolus IVFs and blood for hypotension and tachycardia
* Check lactate and lipase/amylase levels
* Rate control of Afib
* Continued digoxin therapy
* F/u liver recommendations
* Multivitamin therapy
* Platelet transfusion for thrombocytopenia
* Monitoring of renal function
* Hypernatremia management
* Continuation of home regimen of methadone for chronic pain

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Variceal bleeding
* PUD
* Ileus
* Small bowel obstruction (SBO)
* Evolving pancreatitis
* Renal failure
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Infection
* Bleeding complications due to thrombocytopenia

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and his disposition is ICU.

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with an upper GI bleed. The patient has a prolonged bleeding episode, with a marked decrease in hemoglobin and platelet count. The patient has a focal wall motion abnormality on the left ventricle, but overall left ventricular systolic function is normal. The patient has a mild thickening of the aortic valve leaflets, but no aortic stenosis or regurgitation. The patient has a normal right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion.

Potential medical complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient has a prolonged bleeding episode, which may lead to further complications such as anemia, hypovolemic shock, and cardiac instability.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding and other complications.
3. Renal insufficiency: The patient has a history of renal insufficiency, and the use of contrast agents may exacerbate this condition.
4. Liver disease: The patient has cirrhosis, which may increase the risk of bleeding, infection, and other complications.
5. Respiratory complications: The patient has a history of chronic pain and may be at risk for respiratory complications such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
6. Infection: The patient has a prolonged stay in the ICU, which may increase the risk of infection.
7. Pancreatitis: The patient's abdominal pain and elevated lipase levels may indicate pancreatitis, which can be a life-threatening condition.
8. Ileus or small bowel obstruction: The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness may indicate ileus or small bowel obstruction, which can be a life-threatening condition.
9. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has hypernatremia, which may lead to electrolyte imbalance and other complications.
10. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac rhythm is abnormal, which may increase the risk of cardiovascular instability and other complications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management. The patient's bleeding episode needs to be controlled, and his platelet count needs to be normalized. The patient's renal function needs to be closely monitored, and his liver disease needs to be managed. The patient's respiratory status needs to be closely monitored, and he needs to be assessed for infection. The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness need to be evaluated, and he needs to be assessed for pancreatitis or ileus/small bowel obstruction. The patient's electrolyte imbalance needs to be addressed, and his cardiovascular stability needs to be maintained.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Variceal bleed: The patient has a history of upper GI bleed, PUD, and varices, which increases the risk of recurrent variceal bleeding.
2. Infection: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be a sign of infection, and blood and urine cultures are pending. If the cultures are positive, the patient may develop sepsis or septic shock.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications. The patient may require platelet transfusions to maintain a safe platelet count.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient has a history of renal insufficiency, and the creatinine level is still elevated. The patient may require close monitoring of renal function and may require further interventions to manage kidney function.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, which may increase the risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. The patient may require further fluid management to correct the hypernatremia.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which may increase the risk of stroke and thromboembolism. The patient may require anticoagulation therapy to reduce this risk.
7. Liver disease: The patient has cirrhosis, which may increase the risk of liver failure and bleeding complications. The patient may require close monitoring of liver function and may require further interventions to manage liver disease.
8. Chronic pain: The patient has chronic pain, which may require ongoing management with pain medications. The patient may require further assessment and treatment of chronic pain to improve quality of life.

The patient's current condition is critical, and the medical team should closely monitor the patient's vital signs, lab results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications and address them promptly.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with an upper GI bleed. The patient has atrial fibrillation (Afib) and is at risk for variceal bleed vs. PUD. The endoscopy revealed small amount of oozing at the Billroth anastomosis site and Grade I varices. The patient has a marked increase in LUQ tenderness and mid epigastric tenderness, which may be due to ileus, SBO, or evolving pancreatitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Variceal bleed: The patient is at risk for variceal bleed due to his history of cirrhosis and presence of varices. If the bleeding is not controlled, it can lead to hypovolemic shock, multiorgan failure, and increased mortality.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, tenderness, and elevated lipase and amylase levels suggest the possibility of pancreatitis. If left untreated, it can lead to severe complications, including necrosis, abscess, and death.
3. Ileus/SBO: The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, tenderness, and nausea may be due to ileus or SBO. If left untreated, it can lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, and sepsis.
4. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's bleeding and decreased hematocrit may lead to hypovolemic shock, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.
5. Renal insufficiency: The patient's history of renal insufficiency and elevated creatinine levels may worsen if not managed properly.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if not managed with platelet transfusions and treatment of underlying causes.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of indwelling lines and devices may increase the risk of infection, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and history of cardiac disease may increase the risk of cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's bleeding and hematocrit levels closely and consider transfusions if necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's pain and discomfort with morphine and other analgesics.
3. Monitor the patient's abdominal pain and tenderness and consider imaging studies to rule out ileus, SBO, or pancreatitis.
4. Manage the patient's thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions and treatment of underlying causes.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medications accordingly.
7. Consider prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.
8. Consider sedation and analgesia to reduce the patient's discomfort and anxiety.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis presumed due to EtOH abuse, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. He was admitted to the ICU with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) from an anastomotic site, which is suspected to be the source of bleeding. The patient has a history of recurrent UGIB and has undergone multiple abdominal surgeries, including a Billroth II procedure. He is currently receiving treatment for GIB, including proton pump inhibitors, and is being monitored for further bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastomotic leak or dehiscence: The patient's GIB is suspected to be due to an anastomotic leak or dehiscence, which can lead to further bleeding, infection, and potential complications such as sepsis or organ failure.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient has a history of chronic pancreatitis, which can increase his risk of developing acute pancreatitis, particularly if he develops an anastomotic leak or dehiscence.
3. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing an infection, particularly if he develops an anastomotic leak or dehiscence, which can lead to sepsis or organ failure.
4. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's GIB can lead to hemorrhagic shock, particularly if he loses a significant amount of blood, which can lead to organ failure or death.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia can increase his risk of bleeding, particularly if he develops an anastomotic leak or dehiscence.
6. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis can lead to liver failure, particularly if he develops an anastomotic leak or dehiscence, which can increase his risk of bleeding and other complications.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's GIB can lead to respiratory failure, particularly if he develops respiratory complications such as pneumonia or aspiration.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation can increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, particularly if he develops an anastomotic leak or dehiscence.

Based on the patient's history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor him for any signs of complications and to provide aggressive treatment for any signs of bleeding, infection, or organ failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis due to EtOH abuse, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. He was admitted with upper GI bleeding, which is suspected to be from an anastomotic site, possibly with dehiscence and air leak. The patient has been receiving transfusions of PRBCs, FFP, and platelets. He has a history of Afib, which is currently rate-controlled with digoxin. The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, but he has worsening abdominal pain, which is unclear in etiology.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastomotic dehiscence: The patient's upper GI bleeding is suspected to be from an anastomotic site, which could lead to further bleeding and complications.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's abdominal pain could be due to acute pancreatitis, which could worsen his condition.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which could lead to bleeding complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is due to iron deficiency, which could worsen if not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to cirrhosis and his history of EtOH abuse make him prone to infections, including sepsis.
6. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he could develop respiratory complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to his underlying condition and potential infections.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's Afib could lead to cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
8. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis could lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which could worsen his condition and cognitive function.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust transfusions as needed.
2. Repeat EGD in the near future to further evaluate the source of bleeding.
3. Continue PPI and consider adding H2 blockers to reduce acid production.
4. Monitor the patient's abdominal pain and consider imaging studies to evaluate for pancreatitis or other causes.
5. Continue to manage the patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia with transfusions and iron supplementation.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status closely and consider antibiotics and antifungal agents as needed.
7. Consider consulting a liver specialist to further evaluate the patient's cirrhosis and potential complications.
8. Consider consulting a nutritionist to develop a plan for the patient's nutrition and glycemic control.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis presumed due to EtOH, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. He was admitted with a gastrointestinal bleed (GIB) from the anastomotic site, which is suspected to be due to possible dehiscence with contrast and air leak suggested by CT. The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, and his HCT is stable over the past 24 hours.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and his current rhythm is rate-controlled. He also has a history of depression, psychosis, and chronic pain in his bilateral arms and abdomen. The patient has been taking coumadin in the past, but it is unclear if he is currently taking it.

The patient's physical examination reveals a thin and temporal wasting appearance, poor dentition, and tender abdomen with diffuse tenderness and left upper quadrant (LUQ) being the most tender. His vital signs are stable, and his respiratory support is minimal.

Laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient's WBC count is within normal limits, and his HCT is stable. His platelet count is improving, and he is receiving platelet transfusions as needed.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing PPI to manage GIB
2. Repeat EGD in the near future to evaluate the anastomotic site
3. Monitoring HCT every 8 hours
4. Conservative management of abdominal pain
5. Antifungal and antibiotic therapy for possible anastomotic microperforation
6. TPN for anticipated prolonged NPO
7. Echocardiogram to evaluate Afib
8. Liver consult to evaluate cirrhosis
9. Iron supplementation for anemia
10. Platelet transfusions as needed
11. Check for DVT and LUE asymmetric edema
12. ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Anastomotic dehiscence with further bleeding
2. Infection due to antifungal and antibiotic therapy
3. Further abdominal pain and potential bowel obstruction
4. Thrombocytopenia and bleeding complications
5. Anemia and potential bleeding complications
6. Liver failure and potential need for liver transplantation
7. Cardiac complications due to Afib and potential need for cardioversion
8. Pulmonary complications due to prolonged NPO and potential need for mechanical ventilation
9. Nutritional deficiencies due to prolonged NPO and potential need for parenteral nutrition.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis presumed due to EtOH abuse, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. He was admitted with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) and underwent endoscopy, which revealed small varices and a "dusky" patch in the stomach. He has continued to bleed slowly, with a decrease in hemoglobin and platelet count. He has also developed thrombocytopenia and is at risk for further bleeding.

Potential medical complications:

1. Variceal bleeding: The patient has small varices in his stomach, which can lead to further bleeding and complications.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which can increase the risk of bleeding and bleeding complications.
3. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's blood loss and decreased blood volume can lead to hypovolemic shock, which can be life-threatening.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's abdominal pain and elevated lipase levels suggest the possibility of pancreatitis, which can be a serious complication.
5. Ileus or small bowel obstruction: The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness may indicate the possibility of ileus or small bowel obstruction, which can lead to further complications.
6. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of central lines increase his risk of infection, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
7. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, which can indicate kidney damage or failure.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia may indicate an electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to further complications.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's bleeding is being managed with platelet transfusions and PPI therapy. He is also being monitored for signs of further bleeding, pancreatitis, and ileus. His thrombocytopenia is being treated with platelet transfusions, and his renal insufficiency is being monitored. He is also being treated for his hypernatremia and hypokalemia. Further evaluation and management are needed to address his abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and ileus.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information is summarized:

* The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of ethanol cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper GI bleed from anastomosis site.
* The patient has ongoing slow bleed, requiring daily transfusions.
* EGD showed the source of bleeding to be the anastomosis site, which was friable, and also showed one cord of grade 1 esophageal varices.
* The patient has chronic abdominal pain secondary to pancreatitis, but now with acutely worsening abdominal pain this morning.
* The patient has a history of multiple bowel surgeries, which raises concern for SBO.
* The patient has a diagnosis of AFib, which is rate-controlled.
* The patient has a diagnosis of cirrhosis, presumed to be related to ethanol abuse.
* The patient has a diagnosis of anemia, iron deficiency anemia, and thrombocytopenia.
* The patient has a diagnosis of renal insufficiency, with creatinine now improved.
* The patient has a diagnosis of hypernatremia, which has resolved with D5W.
* The patient has a code status of DNR (do not resuscitate).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* SBO (small bowel obstruction) due to the patient's history of multiple bowel surgeries and chronic abdominal pain.
* Bleeding complications due to the patient's ongoing slow bleed and the need for daily transfusions.
* Thrombotic complications due to the patient's thrombocytopenia and the need for platelet transfusions.
* Renal complications due to the patient's history of renal insufficiency and the need for contrast studies.
* Infectious complications due to the patient's history of multiple abdominal surgeries and the need for invasive procedures.
* Cardiovascular complications due to the patient's diagnosis of AFib and the need for anticoagulation therapy.
* Hepatic complications due to the patient's diagnosis of cirrhosis and the need for liver function monitoring.
* Nutritional complications due to the patient's history of chronic abdominal pain and the need for enteral nutrition.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue PPI drip to manage bleeding.
* Consider surgical consult if the patient has ongoing bleeding requiring daily transfusions.
* TID Hcts to monitor platelet count.
* PICC line placement today as unable to get peripherals.
* Liver follow-up to monitor liver function.
* Bolus IVFs/blood for hypotension/tachycardia; hold antihypertensives.
* Get CT abd/pelvis today to evaluate for SBO.
* Get read of CT abd/pelvis from [**Hospital1 632**] (taken to radiology for uploading this morning).
* Stat KUB.
* NPO.
* D/c opioids.
* Check echocardiogram.
* Can continue digoxin; hold other nodal agents for now.
* Liver consult.
* Collateral information.
* Iron supplementation.
* Continue to trend platelet count.
* Transfuse platelets <50, higher threshold if briskly bleeding.
* Evaluate for splenomegaly with CT abd/pelvis.
* Continue to monitor renal function.
* Continue to monitor hypernatremia.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper GI bleed from anastomosis site. He has ongoing slow bleeding, requiring daily transfusions. An EGD showed the source of bleeding to be the anastomosis site, which was friable, with one cord of grade 1 esophageal varices. He has been unable to receive peripheral IVs and has a RIJ placed at OSH, which will need to be pulled and replaced with an IR-guided PICC. The patient is experiencing abdominal pain, which is concerning for SBO, and has a history of pancreatitis. He is also in atrial fibrillation and has a history of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal insufficiency.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. SBO: The patient's abdominal pain and history of multiple bowel surgeries increase the risk of SBO. A CT abdomen/pelvis is ordered to evaluate for air within the stomach wall or contained perforation vs. trapped within folds.
2. Bleeding: The patient's ongoing slow bleeding requires daily transfusions, and the source of bleeding is still uncertain. The patient may require surgical consultation if bleeding continues to be a concern.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he requires platelet transfusions. The cause of thrombocytopenia is unclear, but it may be related to active bleeding, liver disease, hypersplenism, or bone marrow suppression.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level has improved, but it is still elevated. The patient may require further monitoring and potential adjustments to his medication regimen.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation requires rate control, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his cardiac status.

ICU Care Plan:

1. Continue PPI drip to manage bleeding.
2. Consider surgical consultation if bleeding continues to be a concern.
3. Trend platelet count and transfuse platelets as needed.
4. Evaluate for splenomegaly with CT abdomen/pelvis.
5. Monitor creatinine level and adjust medication regimen as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor sodium level and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Manage atrial fibrillation with rate control and further evaluation as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper GI bleed from anastomosis site. He has significant abdominal pain, and the source of the GI bleed is unclear. The patient's HCT is stable, and he is hemodynamically stable. He has a history of Afib, and his liver function tests are abnormal. He is on antibiotics and antifungal medication for possible anastomotic dehiscence. The patient's platelet count is low, and he has received platelet transfusions. He has a history of iron deficiency anemia and is being treated with iron supplementation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastomotic dehiscence: The patient's CT scan showed free air in the mesentery, suggesting a possible anastomotic dehiscence, which can lead to further bleeding, infection, and sepsis.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's abdominal pain and elevated lipase levels suggest the possibility of pancreatitis, which can lead to further complications such as necrosis, abscesses, and sepsis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and abnormal liver function tests suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
4. Bleeding: The patient's low platelet count and history of bleeding make him at risk for further bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death.
5. Infection: The patient's low platelet count and history of bleeding make him at risk for infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
6. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis and abnormal liver function tests suggest the possibility of liver failure, which can lead to further complications such as encephalopathy, bleeding, and death.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's Afib and abnormal cardiac enzymes suggest the possibility of cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's HCT and platelet count.
2. Continue antibiotics and antifungal medication for possible anastomotic dehiscence.
3. Consider repeat EGD to further evaluate the source of the GI bleed.
4. Monitor the patient's abdominal pain and consider further evaluation for pancreatitis.
5. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and consider liver transplant if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further evaluation for cardiac complications.
7. Consider TPN for anticipated long-NPO status.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with an upper GI bleed from an anastomosis site. The patient has been experiencing significant abdominal pain, and the source of the GI bleed is unclear. The patient has been diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hypernatremia. The patient's HCT is stable, and hemodynamically, they are stable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastomotic dehiscence: The patient's CT scan shows free air in the mesentery, which suggests a possible anastomotic dehiscence. This complication can lead to further bleeding, infection, and potential sepsis.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's abdominal pain and CT scan findings suggest a possible acute pancreatitis. This complication can lead to further organ dysfunction, sepsis, and potential multi-organ failure.
3. Infection: The patient's abdominal pain, fever, and white blood cell count suggest a possible infection. This complication can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and potential death.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia can increase the risk of bleeding complications, particularly in the setting of an upper GI bleed.
5. Anemia: The patient's iron deficiency anemia can exacerbate the patient's anemia, leading to further organ dysfunction and potential multi-organ failure.
6. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's significant abdominal pain, bleeding, and potential infection can lead to hypovolemic shock, which can result in organ dysfunction and potential death.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient's underlying condition and potential complications can lead to respiratory failure, particularly in the setting of sepsis or multi-organ failure.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation, potential anastomotic dehiscence, and potential infection can lead to cardiovascular instability, particularly in the setting of sepsis or multi-organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's HCT, platelet count, and white blood cell count to assess for signs of bleeding, infection, or organ dysfunction.
2. Consider repeating the CT scan to assess for further anastomotic dehiscence or other complications.
3. Continue to manage the patient's abdominal pain with conservative measures, and consider further evaluation with endoscopy or CT scan if the pain persists.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, and consider intubation if the patient's respiratory status deteriorates.
5. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with rate control measures, and consider further evaluation with echocardiogram if the patient's cardiac status deteriorates.
6. Consider further evaluation with liver function tests and imaging studies to assess for signs of liver dysfunction or cirrhosis.
7. Consider further evaluation with bone marrow studies to assess for signs of bone marrow suppression or other hematological disorders.
8. Consider further evaluation with neurological studies to assess for signs of neurological dysfunction or other neurological disorders.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with upper GI bleed from anastomosis site and ongoing abdominal pain. The patient has been managed conservatively with PPI drip, and surgery is planned following. The patient's Hct has remained stable over the past 24 hours. The patient has also been diagnosed with microperforation, and management is being undertaken conservatively. The patient's abdominal pain is chronic, secondary to pancreatitis, and is being managed with minimal opioids. The patient remains in atrial fibrillation, and digoxin is being continued. The patient has iron deficiency anemia and thrombocytopenia, and platelet transfusions are being considered. The patient's creatinine levels have improved, and renal function is being monitored. The patient has hypernatremia, which was previously resolved, but has returned. The patient's ICU care includes NPO status, TPN when available, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Microperforation: The patient has a high risk of developing microperforation, which could lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
2. Bleeding: The patient has ongoing abdominal pain and bleeding, which could lead to hemorrhagic shock and death.
3. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing infections, particularly in the abdominal cavity, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
4. Liver Failure: The patient has cirrhosis, which could lead to liver failure and death.
5. Renal Failure: The patient has renal insufficiency, which could lead to renal failure and death.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which could lead to seizures, coma, and death.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which could lead to bleeding and death.
8. Anemia: The patient has iron deficiency anemia, which could lead to anemia-related complications, such as fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding and abdominal pain, and consider surgical intervention if necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's microperforation conservatively, and consider serial abdominal exams and repeat CT scans if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider liver transplantation if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's hypernatremia and consider D5W or D51/2 infusions as necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions as necessary.
7. Consider iron supplementation to manage the patient's iron deficiency anemia.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and consider cardioversion or anticoagulation therapy if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of ethanol cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with an upper gastrointestinal bleed (UGIB) from an anastomotic site. The source of the bleed is unclear, but the prime suspect is the anastomotic site with concern for possible dehiscence and air leak. The patient's hemodynamics are stable, and his HCT is stable over the past 24 hours. He has worsening abdominal pain, and the etiology is unclear. He is on antibiotics and antifungal therapy for possible anastomotic dehiscence.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastomotic dehiscence: The patient's worsening abdominal pain and concern for possible dehiscence at the anastomotic site may lead to further complications such as bleeding, perforation, or peritonitis.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's abdominal pain and possible anastomotic perfusion may lead to acute pancreatitis, which can be life-threatening.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, consumption, or bone marrow suppression.
4. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and recent surgery may increase the risk of infection, particularly with bacteria such as Clostridium difficile.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis and recent bleeding may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status, seizures, or coma.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying lung disease and possible aspiration of gastric contents may lead to respiratory failure.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac complications such as stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiac arrest.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamics, HCT, and abdominal pain.
2. Repeat EGD to further evaluate the source of bleeding and assess the anastomotic site.
3. Consider TPN to anticipate long-NPO status.
4. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy for possible anastomotic dehiscence.
5. Monitor the patient's platelet count and transfuse as necessary.
6. Consider liver consult to further evaluate the patient's cirrhosis.
7. Continue to trend the patient's electrolytes and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis with H2 blockers or sucalfate.
9. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider mechanical ventilation if necessary.
10. Consider cardiology consult to further evaluate the patient's atrial fibrillation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-inch tall individual who presented with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB). The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate. The patient's oxygen saturation is 97% without the use of supplemental oxygen.

The patient's laboratory results indicate anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 11.0 g/dL and a hematocrit of 28.5%. The patient's platelet count is within normal limits. The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 31 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 34 IU/L.

The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L. The patient's glucose level is well-controlled, with a blood sugar level of 105 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen, show free air in the mesentery, which is consistent with a perforation of the small intestine. The patient has been started on intravenous flucloxacillin and zosyn for possible extravasation of contrast into the abdomen.

The patient's physical examination reveals a soft and tender abdomen, with bowel sounds present. The patient's extremities show 1+ edema, and their skin is not jaundiced.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's low white blood cell count and elevated lactate level may indicate an underlying infection, which can lead to sepsis.
2. Intestinal obstruction: The patient's free air in the mesentery may indicate a perforation of the small intestine, which can lead to intestinal obstruction.
3. Peritonitis: The patient's free air in the mesentery may indicate a perforation of the small intestine, which can lead to peritonitis.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated lipase level may indicate pancreatitis, which can lead to severe abdominal pain and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated potassium level may indicate an electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that they receive close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   related.  No heparin exposures.  On PPI, no H2 blockers.

   64 M with EtOH cirrhosis, PUD and multiple abdominal surgeries, and
   Afib, admit with upper GI bleed from anastamosis site also with
   microperforation of bowel.
   1.  UGIB.  Bleeding source may be friability at anastamosis site from
   prior bilroth surgery.  Hct stable.  Now on [**Hospital1 **] PPI IV.  No
   transfusiosn in > 48 hours.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - surgery following
   - [**Hospital1 **] Hcts
   - Access
 retry CVL vs. waiting for Monday for PICC vs. retry
   peripherals.
   - liver following
   - Bolus IVFs/blood for hypotension/tachycardia; hold antihypertensives.
   .
   2.  Air in mesentery.  Concern for microperforations, per surgery,
   perhaps related to scope trauma from OSH EGD.  NPO for three days now.
   Abominal exam improving, but will continue NPO for now. If he remains
   NPO for several more days, will need TPN.  Managing conservatively
   given extensive abdominal surgeries in past, would be difficult
   procedure.
   -          appreciate surgery recs.
   -          Serial abdominal exams
   -          Repeat CT vs. KUB for change in exam.
   -          NPO for today.
   .
   3.       B/l upper extremity clots.  Patient has significant clot
   burden, making line placement difficult.  Unable to anticoagulate at
   present due to GIB.  Cachexia, weight loss, and extensive clot burden
   concerning for malignancy.
   -no anticoagulation in setting of GI bleed
   - outpatient age appropriate cancer screening
   3. Abdominal pain.  Patient has chronic abdominal pain secondary to
   pancreatitis, but with concern for microperforation as above.
   - surgery following.
   - NPO for today
   - minimize opioids
   .
   4.   Afib.   Remains in A. fib, but currently rate controlled.  TTE
   performed this admission.  Not anticoagulated due to GIB.
   - continue digoxin; hold other nodal agents for now
   .
   5.  Cirrhosis.  Well compensated cirrhosis, presumed alcoholic
   related.  Unclear prior workup.
   - Liver following
   - Collateral information if any, ?need to repeat any workup re:
   etiology
   .
   6.  Anemia.  Anemia work up shows iron deficiency anemia.
   - iron supplementation
   7.  Thrombocytopenia.  200 at OSH admission, down to 60 with
   requirement of platelet transfusions.  Consumption with active bleed
   vs. liver disease vs. also consider bone marrow suppression, med
   related.  No heparin exposures.  On PPI, no H2 blockers.
   - Continue to trend.
   - Transfuse platelets <50, higher threshold if briskly bleeding.
   8.   Renal insufficiency.  Creatinine now improved, was up to ~1.9 at
   OSH.  Contrast on [**10-18**].  Per past labs, 0.9 appears to be at baseline.
   - Continue to monitor.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of ethanol cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with an upper gastrointestinal bleed (UGIB) from an anastomosis site with microperforation of the bowel. The patient has a significant clot burden in both upper extremities, making line placement difficult. He is currently not anticoagulated due to the ongoing GI bleed. The patient has a history of chronic abdominal pain secondary to pancreatitis, and is also experiencing anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal insufficiency.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient is at risk of further bleeding due to the ongoing UGIB and the presence of microperforation in the bowel.
2. Clot Burden: The patient's extensive clot burden in both upper extremities may lead to further complications such as pulmonary embolism or stroke.
3. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and recent abdominal surgery increase his risk of developing an infection.
4. Liver Failure: The patient's cirrhosis may progress to liver failure, which could lead to further complications such as bleeding and encephalopathy.
5. Renal Insufficiency: The patient's current renal insufficiency may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further bleeding complications.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as fatigue, weakness, and decreased immune function.
8. Malignancy: The patient's cachexia, weight loss, and extensive clot burden may be indicative of an underlying malignancy, which could lead to further complications if not managed properly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding and clot burden closely, and consider further interventions such as endoscopy or surgery if necessary.
2. Manage the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia with appropriate transfusions and medications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal insufficiency and consider further interventions such as dialysis if necessary.
4. Consider further workup to determine the underlying cause of the patient's cirrhosis and potential malignancy.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and consider further interventions such as liver transplantation if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old with a chief complaint of gastrointestinal bleed. They have undergone an EGD and are receiving fluconazole and zosyn antibiotics. The patient's hemoglobin level has increased from 32.1 to 32.6, and their sodium level has improved from 146 to 142. The patient has extensive clot burden in their upper extremities, including right subclavian and bilateral brachial clots. They are receiving morphine sulfate for pain management and have a code status of DNR (do not resuscitate).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 71 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 153/94 mmHg. Their respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and their oxygen saturation is 98%. The patient has clear breath sounds and is responding to verbal commands.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.7, hemoglobin level of 32.2%, and platelet count of 153. Their creatinine level is 0.9 mg/dL, and their troponin-T level is 0.01 ng/mL. The patient has a mild elevation in their lactate level, but it is within normal limits.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding complications: The patient's gastrointestinal bleed may continue to bleed, and they may require further interventions such as endoscopy or surgery.
2. Thrombotic complications: The patient's extensive clot burden in their upper extremities may increase their risk of thrombotic complications, such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
3. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and recent surgery may increase their risk of infection.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and white blood cell count may indicate sepsis, which requires prompt recognition and treatment.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's troponin-T level is mildly elevated, which may indicate cardiac injury or stress.
6. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory rate is slightly elevated, which may indicate respiratory distress or failure.
7. Nutritional complications: The patient's NPO status may lead to malnutrition and dehydration if not addressed promptly.
8. Medication-related complications: The patient's medication regimen may cause adverse effects, such as bleeding or thrombocytopenia, if not monitored closely.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications and concerns are identified:

1. Upper GI bleed: The patient has a history of upper GI bleed from anastomosis site, which was friable. The source of the bleed is still unknown, and the patient remains on PPI drip.
2. Abdominal pain: The patient has chronic abdominal pain secondary to pancreatitis, and there is concern for microperforation. The patient is being managed conservatively due to extensive abdominal surgeries in the past.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has decreased from 200 to 60, and there is concern for consumption with active bleed, liver disease, or bone marrow suppression. The patient is being transfused platelets <50, with a higher threshold if bleeding is brisk.
4. Anemia: The patient has iron deficiency anemia, and iron supplementation is being considered.
5. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level was elevated at 1.9, but has improved to 0.9. The patient will continue to be monitored.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level was elevated, but has been resolved with D5W. The patient will continue to be monitored.
7. Afib: The patient remains in atrial fibrillation, but is currently rate-controlled. The patient will continue to receive digoxin and hold other nodal agents for now.
8. Cirrhosis: The patient has well-compensated cirrhosis, presumed to be related to alcohol use. The patient will be followed up with liver reevaluation.
9. Microperforation: There is concern for microperforation, particularly related to scope trauma from OSH EGD. The patient is being managed conservatively, and repeat CT or KUB scans may be performed if there is a change in the patient's exam.

The patient's current condition is stable, with no transfusions required in the past 24 hours. The patient's Hct is stable, and the patient is receiving PPI drip for upper GI bleed management. The patient is also receiving IV fluids and blood for hypotension and tachycardia, and antihypertensives are being held. The patient's electrolytes are being monitored, and the patient is being followed up with liver reevaluation. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate).

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted with an upper GI bleed from an anastomotic site. The source of the bleed is unclear, but the prime suspect is the anastomotic site with concern of possible dehiscence with contrast and air leak suggested by CT. The patient has stable hemodynamics and a stable HCT over the past 48 hours. He has a history of right subclavian and bilateral brachial clots, as well as a history of LE DVT, and is unable to anticoagulate at this point due to recent GI bleed and history of multiple prior UGIB.

Medical Complications:

1. Upper GI bleed from anastomotic site, with concern of possible dehiscence and air leak.
2. Bilateral deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper and lower extremities, with a history of LE DVT and a recent history of IVC filter placement.
3. Chronic liver disease with cirrhosis, which may be exacerbated by EtOH consumption.
4. Chronic kidney disease, as indicated by elevated creatinine levels.
5. Chronic pancreatitis, as indicated by elevated amylase and lipase levels.
6. Chronic respiratory disease, as indicated by the patient's requirement for oxygen therapy and the presence of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the patient's history.
7. Cardiovascular disease, as indicated by the patient's history of atrial fibrillation (Afib) and the presence of cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia.
8. Cancer, as indicated by the patient's weight loss and diffuse clots, and the need for cancer screening.
9. Malnutrition, as indicated by the patient's history of weight loss and the need for total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
10. Gastrointestinal bleeding, which may be complicated by the patient's history of PUD and multiple abdominal surgeries.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis or septic shock, particularly in the setting of a compromised immune system due to chronic liver disease and malnutrition.
2. Respiratory failure, particularly in the setting of chronic respiratory disease and the need for oxygen therapy.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias, particularly in the setting of atrial fibrillation and the patient's history of cardiovascular disease.
4. Renal failure, particularly in the setting of chronic kidney disease and the need for TPN.
5. Pancreatitis, particularly in the setting of chronic pancreatitis and the need for TPN.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly in the setting of chronic PUD and multiple abdominal surgeries.
7. Cancer progression, particularly in the setting of diffuse clots and the need for cancer screening.
8. Infection, particularly in the setting of chronic liver disease and malnutrition.
9. Sepsis or septic shock, particularly in the setting of a compromised immune system due to chronic liver disease and malnutrition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of ethanol cirrhosis, peptic ulcer disease, and multiple abdominal surgeries, who was admitted with an upper gastrointestinal bleed from an anastomotic site. The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, and his hemoglobin concentration is stable over the past 24 hours.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 12.7-11.1 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 28.8-32.7%
* Platelet count: 108-153 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.8-1.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.01-0.07 ng/mL
* Glucose: 131-156 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Thin
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Respiratory: No dullness or breath sounds, but with crackles at the bases
* Abdominal: Soft, with bowel sounds present, but with tenderness
* Extremities: Right and left upper extremities (UE) have 1+ edema, with a more pronounced edema on the left side
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, but with no assessment of movement, tone, or reflexes

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Gastrointestinal bleed: likely from the site of gastro-jejunal anastomosis
* Continue proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and plan for repeat endoscopy in the near future
* Monitor hemoglobin concentration every 8 hours today
* Abdominal pain: waxes and wanes in severity, possibly due to anastomotic microperfusion
* Conservative management, with possible surgical intervention
* Anticipated long-term parenteral nutrition (TPN), with possible bridging with peripheral parenteral nutrition (PPN) while working on IV access
* Afib: remains in atrial fibrillation, but currently rate-controlled
* Liver disease: well-compensated cirrhosis, presumed alcoholic-related
* Anemia: iron deficiency anemia
* Thrombocytopenia: improving platelet count, with possible transfusions
* LUE asymmetric edema: check for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Anastomotic site dehiscence
* Air leak
* Contrast leak
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Anastomotic microperfusion
* Infection
* DVT
* Pulmonary embolism
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Liver failure
* Kidney injury
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Bone marrow suppression
* Hypersplenism
* Nutritional deficiencies

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, multiple abdominal surgeries, and Afib, who was admitted with an upper GI bleed from anastamosis site. The source of the GI bleed is unclear, but the prime suspect is the anastomotic site with concern of possible dehiscence with contrast and air leak suggested by CT. The patient has a history of right subclavian and bilateral brachial clots as well as a history of left lower extremity DVT, for which an IVC filter was placed several years ago. He is unable to be anticoagulated at this point due to recent GI bleed and history of multiple prior UGIB.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 71 bpm, blood pressure of 153/94 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on RA. His physical examination is notable for bilateral UE edema, trace LE edema, and engorged veins on the chest wall. His labs show a white blood cell count of 12.7 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 11.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 108 x 10^9/L. His troponin-T level is 0.01 ng/mL, and his lactate level is 1.3 mmol/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Anastomotic leak: The patient's history of GI bleed from anastamosis site suggests a high risk of anastomotic leak, which can lead to sepsis, abscess formation, and further bleeding.
2. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of DVT and PE, as well as his current bilateral UE edema, puts him at high risk for pulmonary embolism.
3. Sepsis: The patient's history of multiple abdominal surgeries and current GI bleed increases his risk for sepsis, particularly if the anastomotic site becomes infected.
4. Kidney injury: The patient's history of cirrhosis and current GI bleed increases his risk for kidney injury, particularly if he develops sepsis or hypovolemic shock.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of Afib and current GI bleed increases his risk for cardiovascular complications, particularly if he develops arrhythmias or cardiac tamponade.
6. Infection: The patient's history of multiple abdominal surgeries and current GI bleed increases his risk for infection, particularly if the anastomotic site becomes infected.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's history of cirrhosis and current NPO status increases his risk for malnutrition, particularly if he develops a prolonged course of illness.
8. Cancer recurrence: The patient's history of weight loss and diffuse clots suggests a high risk for cancer recurrence, particularly if he has a history of cancer.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, PUD, multiple abdominal surgeries, and Afib, admitted with an upper GI bleed from an anastomosis site. The source of the GI bleed is suspected to be the anastomotic site with concern of possible dehiscence. The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), and is unable to anticoagulate due to recent GI bleed and prior UGIB.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 37.1°C, Tcurrent 36.4°C, HR 71 bpm, BP 153/94 mmHg, RR 14 inspirations per minute, SpO2 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Stable
* Fluid balance: 3,119 mL total input, 3,715 mL total output, resulting in a balance of -596 mL
* Respiratory support: SpO2 98% on RA, ABG //30/
* Physical examination: Thin, emaciated, poor dentition, mild diffuse abdominal tenderness, right bilateral UE edema, trace LE edema, engorged veins on chest wall
* Labs: WBC 12.7, Hct 28.8, Plt 108, Cr 0.9, TropT 0.01, Glucose 131, other labs as listed
* Assessment and plan: Continue PPI, plans for repeat EGD in near future, surgery following closely, monitor HCT daily, start TPN for anticipated long-NPO

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Dehiscence of the anastomotic site
* Further bleeding from the anastomotic site
* Development of sepsis due to anastomotic microperforation
* Progression of DVT and PE
* Development of liver failure due to cirrhosis
* Development of kidney failure due to dehydration and/or liver failure
* Development of respiratory failure due to pneumonia or other respiratory complications
* Development of cardiac complications due to Afib and/or other cardiac conditions
* Development of malnutrition due to NPO status and/or other nutritional deficiencies

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.
